The results of the Schiavo autopsy are in.
 
 http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2005/06/15/schiavo_autopsy_shows_no_sign_of_trauma/
 
 In summary, her brain was half the size it should have been, with no recovery possible. Also, her optic centers were badly damaged, meaning she was blind and couldn't have been responding to visual stimuli. Finally, there were no signs of abuse.

If every un-biased professional reaches the same opinion I'll tend to agree with it.
snakespit

Schiavo's Parents Dispute Autopsy Report 
 Thursday, June 16, 2005
 
 LARGO, Fla. - An autopsy that found Terri Schiavo (search) suffered from severe and irreversible brain-damage has done nothing to sway her parents' position that she deserved to live and may have gotten better with therapy. 
 
 The long-awaited report Wednesday found Schiavo's brain had shrunk to about half the normal size for a woman her age when she died March 31 after her feeding tube was disconnected. The autopsy also determined she was blind.
 
 Bob and Mary Schindler (search) disputed the results, insisting their daughter interacted with them and tried to speak. Their attorney said the family plans to discuss the autopsy with other medical experts and may take some unspecified legal action.
 
 http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,159733,00.html 

 
 What don't these people get? Apparently they have now both gone to medical school again and become medical examiners as well as neurologists. emoticon_rolleyes

Batman

He said that there was no evidence of bulimia and the assumption of bulimia presented at the medical malpractice trial had simply been accepted and not challenged. He said there was absolutely nothing to support the theory of bulimia as presented by Michael's attorneys. He also ruled out the 15-year fallacy presented by the mainstream media that she had sustained a heart attack, saying that her collapse was the result of an "external problem outside of the heart causing the heart not to beat". He said there was no evidence that she had had any heart problems prior to her collapse and said that the fact she lived 15 years after her resuscitation was testimony to the strength of her heart.
 STORY

jim's trucking

Hindsight is 20/10!
 
 All who argued that she should be kept alive have yet to be proven wrong in relation to the moral issue connected to euthanasia. Whether her brain was half gone, one third gone, two thirds gone or all gone should not enter into the equation. The fact that she had a beating heart and voluntary breathing functions gave her the right to live, whether she had to be hand fed, tube fed or IV fed. We don't simply let people die when they become unable to feed themselves. We put a spoon of food in their mouths, we hold a glass of water to their lips...we help them eat. Many grandparents and great-grandparents have experienced such caring right up until they died.
 
 It makes no difference whether they are brain dead or not, we shouldn't just let them die UNLESS THEY HAVE PREVIOUSLY MADE WRITTEN ARRANGEMENTS FOR THIS TO HAPPEN.
 
 No such written arrangements existed in this case. That is the only reason that I still fault the system for removing the tube.
 
 ...and Michael Schiavo is still a despicable person for treating her parents the way he did.
Kronus

but there was concern for bias on both sides

 
 That's why I discounted what the doctors hired by both the parents and the husband said. The court appointed doctors, as well as the doctors who worked with Schiavo before the legal fight started, all agreed that she couldn't recover.
Kronus

It makes no difference whether they are brain dead or not, we shouldn't just let them die UNLESS THEY HAVE PREVIOUSLY MADE WRITTEN ARRANGEMENTS FOR THIS TO HAPPEN.

 That is a morally defensible position, but not a legally defensible one. Florida law says that, lacking written instructions, the spouse decides. Unless you want activist judges legislating from the bench than no other outcome was possible. If you want to change the law than go for it, but frankly I'd rather keep the government out of these sorts of decisions.
 
 

 ...and Michael Schiavo is still a despicable person for treating her parents the way he did.

 The parents put him through at least as bad a time, if not worse. They set out, and succeeded, in making him look like a monster, on national tv. If he's despicable, then I can't post what the parents are without violating the forum's decorum rules.
Batman

The parents put him through at least as bad a time, if not worse. They set out, and succeeded, in making him look like a monster, on national tv.

He did a lot of that himself with his own actions like not letting her family know where her ashes were to be buried. Yet somehow that's the family making him out to be a monster.

 
 No, I was more thinking about their malicious accusation of abuse, their allegations that he was doing it for the non-existent money, their erroneous assertions that she was begging for her life. He would be completely within his rights to sue them back to the stone age, and I think it's greatly to his credit that he hasn't.

Every thing that made her what she was, was gone. If that's all been destroyed, why are you so concerned about the body?

That's why I discounted what the doctors hired by both the parents and the husband said. The court appointed doctors, as well as the doctors who worked with Schiavo before the legal fight started, all agreed that she couldn't recover.

 
 
 This is wise when considering potential bias. The parents doctors, hand picked and paid by the parents, had good reason to be biased. Her husbands doctors, also hand picked and well paid, also had reason to show bias. The court appointed doctors had no horse in this race. They were asked for an unbiased opinion and they gave it. Not a single one of them expressed any reservations in thier diagnosis, and they were all well qualified.
 
 
No, I was more thinking about their malicious accusation of abuse, their allegations that he was doing it for the non-existent money, their erroneous assertions that she was begging for her life. He would be completely within his rights to sue them back to the stone age, and I think it's greatly to his credit that he hasn't.

 
 I will certainly agree with this. He is a bigger man than I. Put in the same situation, I would almost certainly retaliate against these people, maybe up to the point of having them killed.
Kronus

No.
 
 Because that "body" took nearly two weeks to die, which in my opinion shows a desire to live.

 
 Yes, but your opinion is based on ideology, and has no medical basis, and so isn't worth anything in this case. You might as well say that a car that runs out of gas was showing a great will to live right up until the final moment. Deprive any machine of fuel and maintenace and it will continue on for a little while, before entropy sets in. That's all that happened. There was no brain, there was no mind, there was no Terri, and so there was no desire. Just a machine, shutting down.

Because that "body" took nearly two weeks to die, which in my opinion shows a desire to live.

At the time of her death, and even at the time the tube was taken out, Terri did not once have one single "desire".

That is the weakest argument I have read on here in a long time. If you understood the anatomy and physiology involved in Terri's case, you would know why it took 2 weeks for her to die. At the time of her death, and even at the time the tube was taken out, Terri did not once have one single "desire".

 
 Because she had no brain, which is a prerequsit to having desires.
snakespit

If your brain is mush, any way is a peaceful way to go.

 Dehydration (not starvation as some people mistakingly say) is a peaceful way to go regardless of the baseline status of your brain. 
 
 
Because she had no brain, which is a prerequsit to having desires.

 She had no cerebral cortex, which is the prereq for desires, feelings, and thoughts. She did however have a cerebellum, which is what provided her with her heartbeat and respiratory drive. So to say she had no brain is not technically correct.
